Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: NSF-JUST Program on Robotic for Rehabilitaion and Medicine

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This joint program reviews the state-of-the-art of the field of model-based assistive robotic technologies for medicine and rehabilitation in the USA and Japan, outlines the fundamental science and technologies in this area, and proposes models for future collaborative research between Japan and USA by building on the mutual strengths. In particular, gait training for stroke patients using exoskeletons is studied.

The field of medical and rehabilitation robotics offers much in terms of broad societal impact. In addition, the project exposes graduate students and faculty to the culture of research in Japan, and more broadly, Asia. Today, Japan leads in many areas of robotics and automation. The students in the NSF-JST program interact with researchers in Japan and visit prominent universities and research laboratories. This exposure provides excellent training for the students and prepares them for careers in industry and academia globally.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this Japan - U.S. Joint Research Program was to meet and exchange ideas with Japanese researchers in the fields of robotics for rehabilitation and surgery. In order to make robotics safe and effective for human applications, robot systems should have appropriate interface based on understanding of human motion, sensation and cognition. The goal was to clarify the common problems for social acceptability of robotic technology such as safety, risk, and potential benefits. The project gave the opportunity to the PI to meet a number of Japanese researchers in medical robotics at workshops and conferences and visit a number of Japanese universities and research laboratories focused in the area of medical robotics. A joint USA-Japan workshop was organized in 2008 at IROS conference. The PI hosted a workshop at Columbia University in 2013 where a research group from University of Tokyo led by Dr. Hajime Asama attended. The PI’s lab hosted a researcher from Nagoya University for a short-term stay in his research group. A joint technical paper was published with this researcher in IEEE Transactions of Robotics in August 2015 focused on the effect of joint misalignment on the performance of gait training exoskeletons. The PI visited National Institute of Technology (NIT) in Japan. This visit has led to exchanges and visits by a Japanese researcher in 2018. A group from NIT robotics held annual robot demonstration at Columbia campus over the three years 2014-2016. These interactions have given a deeper appreciation for research being performed in groups in Japan in the area of medical robotics, their approaches and how the field of rehabilitation robotics can be further developed to impact people and their lives.
